title: Quilt of Souls: A Memoir
author: Elmore, Phyllis Biffle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: UPDATE:2024 listened to the new audiobook version, narrated by the author - added another hit to my heart with this book, and would give it far more sUPDATE:2024 listened to the new audiobook version, narrated by the author - added another hit to my heart with this book, and would give it far more stars than 5, if I could! (thank you NetGalley!)2023 READ:As a quilter, this title is what landed it on my TBR shelf. As a reader, it was the depth and breadth of the story Phyllis Biffle Elmore tells that kept it in my days, to read a little at a time over months this year. The combined wisdom, tragedy, courage and fierceness that comes back to us in all these chapters, and those within each memory. . . all caught up in the bits of clothes - worn over a long life and gathered in a bag, to be thoughtfully chosen for just the right spot in a quilt of souls for some particular person to treasure.Quilting now is very different, boutique-y, arty, for walls and shows - a very different animal. My favorite quilts are the ones of scraps, bits from someone's stash to piece in a similarly thoughtful way, but still is so far removed from the true quilts of the past and the beauties made by Lula Horn.Five pointed stars, quilted and bound up with gratitude for sharing this deeply rooted family tree and its many resilient leaves....more

title: East of Eden
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are books you read that are books. There are books you read that are places. East of Eden has become one of those . . .it retains the power of aThere are books you read that are books. There are books you read that are places. East of Eden has become one of those . . .it retains the power of a portal with whispered invitations to return. . .and I will.Families are messed up and have been for generations. Steinbeck captures that aspect, without losing a drop of the virtues the members of families bring to their tribes. His characters grabbed me and kept me close - even Cathy, wicked, evil Cathy. As for best, who'd I love most? Lee. Definitely Lee.Steinbeck's descriptions of a California I've been through so many times on my way South, haunt me. He painted it perfectly, the golds, the hot warmth - like breath, the shine of the air that makes you squint, with or without sunglasses. And there's a grassy, leaf dust smell and sparkle that the breezes toss around; on sterner days it's an actual wind that moves the world around.As for substance - what caught me there? The themes, the philosophies mingled with scripture: timshel. . .free will, agency, choice - which for you, which for now? good? evil? is there a right or wrong here? you choose. you. choose. choice is ever an option, always available, don't think it's not.Priceless, this book. A treasure....more

title: Precious Bane
author: Webb, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was at a love-spinning that I saw Kester first. . . .Kester says that all tales, true tales or romancings, go farther back than the days of the chiIt was at a love-spinning that I saw Kester first. . . .Kester says that all tales, true tales or romancings, go farther back than the days of the child; aye, farther even than the little babe in its cot of rushes. . . .a nice clean cradle they made, soft and green, so that the babe could feel as big-sorted as a little caterpillar (painted butterflies-as-is-to-be, Kester calls them) sleeping in its cocoon. Kester's very set about such things. Never will he say caterpillars. He'll say, "There's a lot of butterflies-as-is-to-be on our cabbages, Prue." He won't say "It's winter." He'll say, "Summer's sleeping." And there's no bud little enough nor sad-coloured enough for Kester not to callen it the beginnings of the blow. . ."So starts out Mary Webb in her book about Prudence Sarn of Sarn, a place in Shropshire, England. I found a page overlapping poetry and flowers, Blossom vs Bloom vs Flower vs Blow which helped me out in the above-given start of the book: Blow, in this sense, has an archaic or poetic flavor except in the combination "full-blown". Usually it suggest a bursting into flower or bloom and often, especially in the noun, connotes a great display of blooms. . . . .Blow, by far the least frequent of these terms in such use, implies a BURSTING into beauty or perfection.On one hand this is a very old book - almost 100 years ago written, and the subject era is centuries before that - YET, it has a young woman in a community with a flurry of other young women working toward the community good and at the same time are thinking about young men, any men and pairing up. About parties, about family life to come, or not, or those who choose a different direction. . .all those same concerns wherever people are, then and now. Party games happen, songs and music of its time and day, skirts flouncing, clothes that make the woman or the man, and worries over giving trinkets, kerchiefs or whatever the love currency of the day is. . .The storyline wrapped around a girl, flawed and anxious. She is hare-shotten in a time that has no surgical remedy. Those around her ensure she is constantly reminded of it. Not out of any kind of sympathy or compassion, just a knock in the heart to remind her that she needs to be tough, pragmatic and understand she's not one of the pretty or even normal girls in the world. Her's will not be the fate to be a mother: because she's not lovable (read: not f**kable, not even kissable). Who would kiss that mouth?I fell in love with Prue, her bravery and her belief that her one crumb of happiness could carry her through life, and it did. . .until her argument was shut-down in the best way all such arguments can be shut-down. . .and *boom* ?*blow?*. . .waaaay better than a crumb. . ....more

This Dad just moves it up a notch to Shakespeare.All that said, and thousands of s later, I throw in my 4 stars. I liked the sisters, fighting and biting and then remembering who they were. That's what sisters do from time to time. review: The elements of this story that hit me in my heart were these: * the power of shared treasured and precious clothing to create power in relationships The elements of this story that hit me in my heart were these: * the power of shared treasured and precious clothing to create power in relationships (as in who is most "powerful" - wears it best) and power through the illusion gained in the outer world by the wearing of the Schiaparelli gown * the clear difference between Nicholas's catting around and any of the main female characters catting around - boys will be boys, and then awwww he goes religious - girls? just two roads, and beauty leads down the wrong one * the sharp judgment found in MS's works about slender persons and fat ones - virtues, vices and consequences are relentless and concrete * Muriel Spark's writing compels me. . . .I will continue my bookish journey and read as many as I can of her works - and revisiting her works already read is a delight as my heart picks up new bits as I do....more

title: Mortal Weather: A Novel
author: McCarthy, K.P.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Give me a Stanhope Ellis any day. . .he's a sorta hero, a regular hero - the kind your dad was (if he was a good sort). The one who might not have TheGive me a Stanhope Ellis any day. . .he's a sorta hero, a regular hero - the kind your dad was (if he was a good sort). The one who might not have The Answer, and probably not Your Answer but you run to him anyway. And he's not cemented in his manliness, but he is in his humanity and his flaws are . . .awkwardly familiar.Then there is Gayathri Das, a nurse and sister of Anshu Das. She's humanity at its best, too. Only maybe even more loveable. Then there are about 99+ more characters, including humans and non-humans (earthly and non-earthly). As the story unraveled, I began with notes, but gave up - and was relieved to find an index at book's end. It was perfectly placed, a delight to read. I wasn't crazy! There were a lot of side bits. But as I went down the list. . .it wouldn't have been a better story if even one of them had been left out. . .like the linking stitches in a sweater, Stanhope's story-sweater hung together. I couldn't leave it alone.Chapters built on seasonal changes and weather moved the story along, punching in with life's worst troubles. Stan's deepest fear, proved true, over and over: he's a deathmonger. You know that guy, the black cloak and bony pointing finger? And this terrifying possibility: it is catching. To know Stanhope is to die (before your time, probably). What does a caring human do when they land on this realization about themselves? What is the right thing to do? Essential questions are posed, and the story goes, steady on. Words flow, bouncing from page first to page last by life's currents and wind. As you wonder on Stanhope's trajectory and responses to it, you'll inevitably ponder on your own.Oh, in case, fellow Reader, should you worry about open-ended or woebegone conclusions, toss that worry behind you. It won't be found here. This is a wonderful read - I was reminded of John Irving, without all the pages, but keeping the plethora of necessary characters. I didn't want it to end, and I'm looking forward to more from this author. Once this is published, I'll follow up with quotes, because there are a great many good ones!*A sincere thank you to Kevin Patrick McCarthy, Top Reads Publishing LLC and BookSirens for a free ARC to read and voluntarily .* Publication date: Sep 26, 2023...more

review: Harry is not a swell fella. Neither are his folks, so there's that - he can't take all the blame. I rode this pony to the very end, hoping for a concrHarry is not a swell fella. Neither are his folks, so there's that - he can't take all the blame. I rode this pony to the very end, hoping for a concrete reason (message to Reader) to spend all this time with Harry, and came away rather dismayed to not be clear on many things. I admit and own that I do not understand many parts of Harry's story, and it is my fault, I'm sure. Here's what I think I get: * Harry is a white person who thinks he has black sensibilities, mostly * Harry is wrong about that, in a big way * Huzzah for Harry leaving home - that's better for all concerned (so their individual leanings no longer lean on and harm others in their family group) * Maryam (a Nigerian woman) rocked, hard - still don't know why she stuck around, tho * Harry is all about Harry to the very end Here's what has me lost in the weeds: * Harry needed to be set straight just about every day - why didn't that happen?  * Maryam. . .again. Tolerant too long.  * The Very End - ?Perhaps a brighter light will shine for me in a future read, and if so, I will here update.*A Sincere Thank You to Chinelo Okparanta, Mariner Books, and NetGalley for an ARC to read and .* #HarrySylvesterBird #NetGalley...more

title: George VI and Elizabeth: The Marriage That Saved the Monarchy
author: Smith, Sally Bedell*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: George VI and Elizabeth: The Marriage That Saved the Monarchy proved its title true to this reader. Prior to reading this book, my knowledge was limitGeorge VI and Elizabeth: The Marriage That Saved the Monarchy proved its title true to this reader. Prior to reading this book, my knowledge was limited to knowing George VI and Elizabeth (from Scotland) were Elizabeth (from England) II's parents, Himself possessed of a stubborn stutter, played by Colin Firth on the Big Screen, and Herself being a Darling Ancient Granny who looked like she could wield a mean "fish eye" even from under those size-of-a-toaster hats.When the title came into view, my nose wrinkled and my thought was, ?Really? saved the monarchy? Aren't royals forever, over there? Well, this side of the read (long, well-researched, forthcoming and very readable) I'm convinced. This truly would have been a terrible world if those two hadn't set up certain possibilities on that little island of this world during that exact time. I couldn't begin to convince you, dear reader, so won't try. However, to bring up what they gave you and I (and we probably aren't even UK citizens) is the opportunity for peace in a way that never would have happened if all had gone as it was "planned" to go. That is to say giving King Edward VIII (David, Duke of Windsor, Hubby of The Wallis) the throne on his terms (i.e. Queen Wallis) and his continued rule as a Hitler/Nazi fan, buddies-forever paperwork had already been started when the people of England pulled that plug (thank you!). But there had to be someone willing to step up (and there were), but Bertie (George VI is his king name) and his Elizabeth were not headed for a kingly track at all. . . but abdication changed it all. They stepped up to the plate and dedicated themselves and generations of their family to the monarchy.The author had been given access by the Royals (esp Elizabeth II) to the letters, journals, diaries of the many, many players in all these periods of the lives of George VI and Elizabeth from the start to the finish of both of their lives. It was interesting and thorough, with great photos to give context and insight into their work and dedication, as well as the incredible challenges they faced: world wars, colonial empire imploding, economic struggles and on-island questions about the monarchy construct and its relevancy. This book doesn't try to answer any of those - it simply provides a reader the view in the window (balcony?) as to what they faced. More than once my still small voice was yelling "RUN!"Highly recommended for anyone who follows the Royals or is interested in that particular period of England's history. Well done, Ms. Smith!*A sincere thank you to Sally Bedell Smith, Random House Publishing Group, and NetGalley for an ARC to read and independently * #GeorgeVIandElizabeth #NetGalley...more

title: The Lottery Ticket
author: Chekhov, Anton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm dipping my toes in the Chekov pool, and this was a very compelling read. The rush of excitement, to thrills brought on by the idea of wealth and uI'm dipping my toes in the Chekov pool, and this was a very compelling read. The rush of excitement, to thrills brought on by the idea of wealth and unlimited resources, and having every nagging bill paid, with more to spare. . . .followed by those gathering arms pulling all that gold into YOUR pot, not theirs. . .the hunching over, beady eyes watchful for a wandering hand that might try and slide some away from your pile. . . it was all very dragon-in-the-gold-tolkieny. . .Both husband and wife have their versions of the above joy-to-excitement-to greed-to. . .the stunning realization that now that this has happened, you'll never be the same as you were the moments before the possibility of winning the lottery flashed your existence to pieces. Whether you win or lose, doesn't matter. Your piddly bit of life's pie is pale and tasteless in the whole scheme of things. Your happy partnership is anything but. . .I had to shake my head hard after this read, this quick, lightening strike of a read. It would take a very strong person to bring themselves back from the edge of this windfall. I, of course, stopped buying lottery tickets immediately....more

title: My Twentieth Century Evening and Other Small Breakthroughs: The Nobel Lecture
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a short, deeply profound read. I go back to it over and over, and he says it best himself, so I will leave it in his hands:“My Nobel appeal: iThis is a short, deeply profound read. I go back to it over and over, and he says it best himself, so I will leave it in his hands:“My Nobel appeal: it’s hard to put the whole world to rights, but let us at least think about how we can prepare our own small corner of it, this corner of literature where we read, write, publish, recommend, denounce, and give awards to books. If we are to play an important role in this uncertain future, if we are to get the best from the writers of today and tomorrow, I believe we must become more diverse. I mean this in two particular senses.Firstly, we must widen our common literary world to include many more voices from beyond our comfort zones of the elite first world cultures. We must search more energetically to discover the gems from what remain today unknown literary cultures, whether the writers live in faraway countries or within our own communities.Second, we must take great care not to set too narrowly or conservatively our definitions of what constitutes good literature. The next generation will come with all sorts of new, sometimes bewildering ways to tell important and wonderful stories. We must keep our minds open to them, especially regarding genre and form, so that we can nurture and celebrate the best of them. In a time of dangerously increasing division we must listen. Good writing and good reading will break down barriers. We may even find a new idea, a great humane vision around which to rally.”...more
